bestBHT.bht: You have no hatred of the world in your way, but its hatred to Me on account of my testimony against it causes me to exercise this caution which you so blame. It is an inherent impossibility for the unbelieving world, unable to love Jesus, to hate you who belong to it. Jesus and His brothers stand in opposite relations to the world, as He is the Reprover of its wicked works.

Henry Alford: You have no hatred of the world in your way.
But its hatred to Me on account of my testimony against it, causes me to exercise this caution which you so blame.
Causes me to exercise this caution which you so blame.
Albert Barnes: You profess no principles in opposition to the world.
As you possess the same spirit and principles with the men of the world, they cannot be expected to hate you.
We may expect that all who preach faithfully against the wickedness of men will excite opposition.
Marvin Vincent: Cannot. Frequent in John, and expressing an inherent impossibility. See John 3:3, John 3:5; John 5:19; John 6:44; John 7:34, John 7:36; John 8:21, John 8:43; John 12:39; John 14:17, etc. Evil [πονηρα] . See on Luke 3:19; Luke 7:21.
John Calvin: Peace with the world can only be purchased by a wicked consent to vices and to every kind of wickedness.
All who have not yet been regenerated by the Spirit are Christ’s adversaries.
So great is the pride natural to men, that they flatter and applaud themselves in their vices.
Philip Schaff: The world cannot hate you; but me it hateth, because I bear witness concerning it, that its works are wicked.
Jesus takes up the word which they had used; but in His mouth it has a depth of solemn meaning of which they knew nothing.
Jesus and His brothers stand in opposite relations to the world, they at one with it, He the Reprover of its wicked works.
Archibald T. Robertson: Cannot hate. Because of "the law of moral correspondence" (Westcott), often in John for "inherent impossibility" (Vincent)."
The brothers of Jesus here belong to the unbelieving world (κοσμος) which is unable to love Jesus.
John Gill: The world cannot hate you,.... Because they were of the world, belonged to it; they were like unto it, and every like loves its like..."
but me it hateth; though without a cause; that is, without a just cause, or reason..."
because I testify of it, that the works thereof are evil...
John Wesley: The world cannot hate you — Because ye are of the world.
But me it hateth — And all that bear the same testimony.

bhtAttempts.bht: You do not hold any animosity towards the world, but the world despises me because I testify against its wickedness. It is because of the inherent impossibility of the world to hate those who are like it, that it cannot hate you, my brothers. However, it hates me because I bear witness that its works are evil. This opposition from the unbelieving world is a result of their resentment towards being exposed. As Jesus and his brothers stand in opposite relations to the world, with his brothers being at one with it while he reproves its wicked works, it is expected that preaching against the wickedness of men will provoke opposition.

You do not hold any animosity towards the world, but the world despises me because I testify against its wickedness. It is because of the inherent impossibility of the world to hate those who are like it that it cannot hate you, my brothers. This opposition from the unbelieving world is a result of their resentment towards being exposed. As Jesus and his brothers stand in opposite relations to the world, with his brothers being at one with it while he reproves its wicked works, it is expected that preaching against the wickedness of men will provoke opposition.

The world cannot hate you because you have no hatred of the world in your way. However, it hates me because I bear witness against its wickedness. This opposition from the unbelieving world is a result of their resentment towards being exposed. As Jesus and his brothers stand in opposite relations to the world, it is expected that preaching against the wickedness of men will provoke opposition.

You have no hatred of the world in your way, but its hatred to Me on account of my testimony against it causes me to exercise this caution which you so blame. It is an inherent impossibility for the unbelieving world, unable to love Jesus, to hate you who belong to it. Jesus and His brothers stand in opposite relations to the world, as He is the Reprover of its wicked works. All who preach faithfully against the wickedness of men will excite opposition, for those submerged in the pride of their vices cannot bear to have their works exposed.

You have no hatred of the world in your way, but its hatred to Me on account of my testimony against it causes me to exercise this caution which you so blame. It is an inherent impossibility for the unbelieving world, unable to love Jesus, to hate you who belong to it. Jesus and His brothers stand in opposite relations to the world, as He is the Reprover of its wicked works.
